channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: World's first wooden satellite could herald era of greener space exploration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01456-z

Japan’s satellite will test wood's resilience in space — wooden Moon shelters are also planned.
item.dc:title: World's first wooden satellite could herald era of greener space exploration
item.dc:creator: Tim Hornyak

item.title: ‘Rainbow’, ‘like a cricket’: every bird in South Africa now has an isiZulu name
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01678-1

An effort to create names for wild bird species in the Indigenous language hopes to strengthen conservation research.
item.dc:title: ‘Rainbow’, ‘like a cricket’: every bird in South Africa now has an isiZulu name
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wild

item.title: A huge outbreak of butterflies hit three continents — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01653-w

Swarms of painted ladies that descended on the Middle East, northern Africa and Europe have been traced to their source.
item.dc:title: A huge outbreak of butterflies hit three continents — here’s why

Widespread horse-based mobility arose around 2,200 BCE in Eurasia

item.title: Why female students at an inner London school are seeing scientists in a different light
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01689-y

Julie Gould describes what happened after showing 50 images of working scientists to a bunch of 12–13 year-olds.
item.dc:title: Why female students at an inner London school are seeing scientists in a different light
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: I was denied tenure — how do I cope?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01694-1

Researchers can work long and hard for a permanent academic position, only for their hopes to be dashed. Nature sought advice from three scientists who have experienced the same disappointment.
item.dc:title: I was denied tenure — how do I cope?
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: What’s the best way to tackle climate change? An ‘evidence bank’ could help scientists find answers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01683-4

Synthesizing research on which policies are most effective is a key priority in climate science, advocates say.
item.dc:title: What’s the best way to tackle climate change? An ‘evidence bank’ could help scientists find answers
item.dc:creator: Helen Pearson

item.title: CERN’s $17-billion supercollider in question as top funder criticizes cost
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01671-8

Germany has raised doubts about the affordability of the Large Hadron Collider’s planned successor.
item.dc:title: CERN’s $17-billion supercollider in question as top funder criticizes cost
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Do scientists make good presidents? How five national leaders performed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01693-2

Following Mexico’s election result, Nature reviews the legacy of well-known politicians with backgrounds in science and engineering.
item.dc:title: Do scientists make good presidents? How five national leaders performed
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty
Jeff Tollefson
Carissa Wong

item.title: Structure and topography of the synaptic V-ATPase–synaptophysin complex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07610-x

Structure and topography of the synaptic V-ATPase–synaptophysin complex
item.dc:title: Structure and topography of the synaptic V-ATPase–synaptophysin complex

Author Correction: High-speed and large-scale intrinsically stretchable integrated circuits

item.title: China seeks global impact and recognition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01595-3

The country’s lead in high-quality research looks set to shape the direction of world science.
item.dc:title: China seeks global impact and recognition
item.dc:creator: Simon Baker

item.title: AI finds huge cache of anti-bacterial peptides hidden in genomic data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01654-9

Machine-learning technique uncovers nearly 900,000 microbe-fighting peptide sequences in genomes collected from soils and other sources.
item.dc:title: AI finds huge cache of anti-bacterial peptides hidden in genomic data

item.title: These Neanderthal fire pits offer an extraordinarily precise snapshot of ancient life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01688-z

Researchers used traces of Earth’s changing magnetic field in sediments to identify the activity of ancient humans.
item.dc:title: These Neanderthal fire pits offer an extraordinarily precise snapshot of ancient life
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: A virally encoded high-resolution screen of cytomegalovirus dependencies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07503-z

A genetic screen that expresses single guide RNA libraries targeting host genes in the human cytomegalovirus genome enables identification of host factors and provides insights into their roles during the viral replication cycle.
item.dc:title: A virally encoded high-resolution screen of cytomegalovirus dependencies
item.dc:creator: Yaara Finkel
Aharon Nachshon
Einav Aharon
Tamar Arazi
Elena Simonovsky

Tal Fisher
Richard J. Stanton

Noam Stern-Ginossar

item.title: A disease-associated gene desert directs macrophage inflammation through ETS2
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07501-1

ETS2—which is associated with inflammatory bowel disease, ankylosing spondylitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis and Takayasu’s arteritis—is a central regulator of human inflammatory macrophages.
item.dc:title: A disease-associated gene desert directs macrophage inflammation through ETS2

item.title: Profiling phagosome proteins identifies PD-L1 as a fungal-binding receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07499-6

Proximity labelling of phagosomal contents is used to identify proteins that localize to phagosomes in host–microorganism interactions.
item.dc:title: Profiling phagosome proteins identifies PD-L1 as a fungal-binding receptor
item.dc:creator: Kai Li
Avradip Chatterjee
Chen Qian
Katherine Lagree

David M. Underhill

item.title: MYCT1 controls environmental sensing in human haematopoietic stem cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07478-x

MYCT1 is identified as a crucial regulator of cellular properties essential for the stemness of human haematopoietic stem cells, a finding that may help improve successful in vitro expansion of these cells for therapeutics.
item.dc:title: MYCT1 controls environmental sensing in human haematopoietic stem cells
item.dc:creator: Júlia Aguadé-Gorgorió
Yasaman Jami-Alahmadi

Maya Kardouh

item.title: Observation of 2D-magnesium-intercalated gallium nitride superlattices
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07513-x

The spontaneous formation of magnesium-intercalated gallium nitride superlattices by the interstitial intercalation of two-dimensional magnesium results in considerable compressive strain perpendicular to the layers, leading to enhanced hole transport.
item.dc:title: Observation of 2D-magnesium-intercalated gallium nitride superlattices
item.dc:creator: Jia Wang
Wentao Cai
Weifang Lu
Shun Lu
Emi Kano

Makoto Nakajima
Yoshio Honda
Hiroshi Amano

item.title: Fault-network geometry influences earthquake frictional behaviour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07518-6

Analysis of some of the main fault zones in California shows that the presence of complex earthquake fault-network geometries results in geometric locking that promotes stick-slip behaviour, whereas simpler geometries lead to smooth fault creep.
item.dc:title: Fault-network geometry influences earthquake frictional behaviour
item.dc:creator: Jaeseok Lee
Victor C. Tsai
Greg Hirth
Avigyan Chatterjee
Daniel T. Trugman

item.title: Injectable ultrasonic sensor for wireless monitoring of intracranial signals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07334-y

A bioresorbable, wireless hydrogel (metagel) sensor, encompassing both biodegradable and stimulus-responsive hydrogels for ultrasonic monitoring of intracranial signals, was implanted into intracranial space with a puncture needle and deformed in response to physiological environmental changes.
item.dc:title: Injectable ultrasonic sensor for wireless monitoring of intracranial signals
item.dc:creator: Hanchuan Tang
Yueying Yang

item.title: A late-Ediacaran crown-group sponge animal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07520-y

Cross-hatch impressions from Ediacaran rocks in China are interpreted as having been left by a crown-group sponge fossil, Helicolocellus cantori gen. et sp. nov., characterized by an organic latticework skeleton.
item.dc:title: A late-Ediacaran crown-group sponge animal
item.dc:creator: Xiaopeng Wang
Alexander G. Liu
Zhe Chen
Chengxi Wu
Yarong Liu
Bin Wan
Ke Pang
Chuanming Zhou
Xunlai Yuan
Shuhai Xiao

item.title: Myelin plasticity in the ventral tegmental area is required for opioid reward
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07525-7

Oligodendrogenesis is shown to be involved in reward learning, with dopaminergic neuronal activity-regulated myelin plasticity being an important reward circuit modification.
item.dc:title: Myelin plasticity in the ventral tegmental area is required for opioid reward
item.dc:creator: Belgin Yalçın
Matthew B. Pomrenze
Karen Malacon
Richard Drexler
Abigail E. Rogers

Daniel Contreras-Esquivel

Michelle Monje

item.title: Misunderstanding the harms of online misinformation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07417-w

This Perspective identifies common misperceptions regarding the harms of online misinformation, finding that exposure to false and inflammatory content is rare and concentrated among a small minority of people who already have extreme views.
item.dc:title: Misunderstanding the harms of online misinformation
item.dc:creator: Ceren Budak
Brendan Nyhan
David M. Rothschild
Emily Thorson
Duncan J. Watts

item.title: Early stages of covalent organic framework formation imaged in operando
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07483-0

The operando imaging of the early formation stages of covalent organic frameworks with the optical technique interferometric scattering microscopy leads to mechanistic insights, enabling the rational development of a synthesis protocol at room temperature instead of elevated temperatures.
item.dc:title: Early stages of covalent organic framework formation imaged in operando
item.dc:creator: Christoph G. Gruber
Laura Frey
Roman Guntermann
Dana D. Medina
Emiliano Cortés

item.title: Nuclear position and local acetyl-CoA production regulate chromatin state
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07471-4

Analyses of histone acetylation in Drosophila wing imaginal discs reveal distinct patterns of acetylation and cellular metabolism that affect gene expression and cell specification.
item.dc:title: Nuclear position and local acetyl-CoA production regulate chromatin state
item.dc:creator: Philipp Willnow
Aurelio A. Teleman

item.title: The time between Palaeolithic hearths
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07467-0

High-resolution time differences between six Middle Palaeolithic hearths from El Salt Unit x (Spain) obtained through archaeomagnetic and archaeostratigraphic analyses show sometimes decade-long intervals between hearths.
item.dc:title: The time between Palaeolithic hearths
item.dc:creator: Ángela Herrejón-Lagunilla
Juan José Villalaín
Francisco Javier Pavón-Carrasco
Mario Serrano Sánchez-Bravo
Santiago Sossa-Ríos
Alejandro Mayor
Bertila Galván
Cristo M. Hernández
Carolina Mallol
Ángel Carrancho

item.title: Senescent glia link mitochondrial dysfunction and lipid accumulation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07516-8

The authors identify naturally occurring senescent glia in aged Drosophila brains and decipher their origin and influence, determining that they can appear in response to neuronal mitochondrial dysfunction and that they promote lipid accumulation, indicating that these cells link key ageing phenomena.
item.dc:title: Senescent glia link mitochondrial dysfunction and lipid accumulation
item.dc:creator: China N. Byrns
Alexandra E. Perlegos
Karl N. Miller
Zhecheng Jin

Nancy M. Bonini

item.title: Descending networks transform command signals into population motor control
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07523-9

Command-like descending neurons in Drosophila melanogaster recruit additional descending neuronal networks to co-ordinate behaviours that require multiple motor subroutines controlling numerous body parts.
item.dc:title: Descending networks transform command signals into population motor control
item.dc:creator: Jonas Braun
Femke Hurtak
Sibo Wang-Chen
Pavan Ramdya

item.title: Large-area, self-healing block copolymer membranes for energy conversion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07481-2

We introduce a self-assembly strategy that uses the interface of an aqueous two-phase system to template and stabilize molecularly thin biomimetic block copolymer bilayers of scalable area that can exceed 10 cm2 without defects.
item.dc:title: Large-area, self-healing block copolymer membranes for energy conversion
item.dc:creator: Christian C. M. Sproncken
Peng Liu

item.title: Scaling neural machine translation to 200 languages
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07335-x

Scaling neural machine translation to 200 languages is achieved by No Language Left Behind, a single massively multilingual model that leverages transfer learning across languages.
item.dc:title: Scaling neural machine translation to 200 languages

item.title: Global shortfalls in documented actions to conserve biodiversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07498-7

A global assessment of conservation interventions for threatened species across a range of data sources finds that interventions for most species remain insufficient or absent.
item.dc:title: Global shortfalls in documented actions to conserve biodiversity
item.dc:creator: Rebecca A. Senior
Ruby Bagwyn
Danyan Leng
Alexander K. Killion
Walter Jetz
David S. Wilcove

item.title: Epigenetic inheritance of diet-induced and sperm-borne mitochondrial RNAs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07472-3

A study shows that epididymal spermatozoa are sensitive to preconception diet, identifies mitochondrial tRNAs and their fragments as sperm-borne factors and demonstrates epigenetic inheritance of mitochondrial tRNAs.
item.dc:title: Epigenetic inheritance of diet-induced and sperm-borne mitochondrial RNAs
item.dc:creator: A. Tomar

item.title: Microbial competition for phosphorus limits the CO<sub>2</sub> response of a mature forest
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07491-0

Microbial pre-emption of mineralized soil P limits the capacity of trees for increased P uptake and assimilation under elevated CO2 and therefore restricts their capacity to sequester extra C.
item.dc:title: Microbial competition for phosphorus limits the CO<sub>2</sub> response of a mature forest
item.dc:creator: Mingkai Jiang
Kristine Y. Crous
Yolima Carrillo
Catriona A. Macdonald

Benjamin Smith
Belinda E. Medlyn
David S. Ellsworth

item.title: Capturing carbon dioxide from air with charged-sorbents
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07449-2

Charged-sorbents are a new class of designer sorbent materials for the capture of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, and can be regenerated at low temperatures with direct heating generation using renewable electricity.
item.dc:title: Capturing carbon dioxide from air with charged-sorbents
item.dc:creator: Huaiguang Li
Mary E. Zick

Valentina Crocellà

Alexander C. Forse

item.title: Companies inadvertently fund online misinformation despite consumer backlash
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07404-1

Many companies unknowingly advertise on websites that publish misinformation despite the reputational and financial risks, and increased transparency for consumers and advertisers could counter unintended ad revenue going to misinformation websites.
item.dc:title: Companies inadvertently fund online misinformation despite consumer backlash
item.dc:creator: Wajeeha Ahmad
Ananya Sen
Charles Eesley
Erik Brynjolfsson

item.title: Single-cell nascent RNA sequencing unveils coordinated global transcription
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07517-7

Nascent transcription in genes and enhancers genome-wide at the single-cell level is quantified using global run-on and sequencing (GRO–seq) with click chemistry.
item.dc:title: Single-cell nascent RNA sequencing unveils coordinated global transcription
item.dc:creator: Dig B. Mahat
Nathaniel D. Tippens
Jorge D. Martin-Rufino
Sean K. Waterton
Jiayu Fu
Sarah E. Blatt
Phillip A. Sharp

item.title: Observation of edge states derived from topological helix chains
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07484-z

Unusual electronic states derived from topological helix chains were observed that support the emergent bound states in elemental tellurium.
item.dc:title: Observation of edge states derived from topological helix chains
item.dc:creator: K. Nakayama
A. Tokuyama
K. Yamauchi
A. Moriya
T. Kato

T. Sato

item.title: Post-January 6th deplatforming reduced the reach of misinformation on Twitter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07524-8

Difference-in-differences analysis indicates that the decision by Twitter to deplatform 70,000 users following the events at the US Capitol on 6 January 2021 had wider effects on the spread of misinformation.
item.dc:title: Post-January 6th deplatforming reduced the reach of misinformation on Twitter
item.dc:creator: Stefan D. McCabe
Diogo Ferrari
Jon Green
David M. J. Lazer
Kevin M. Esterling

item.title: Visualization of oxygen vacancies and self-doped ligand holes in La3Ni2O7−δ
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07482-1

Direct visualization of oxygen vacancies and self-doped ligand holes reveals the role of ligand oxygen in La3Ni2O7−δ and provides further understanding of superconducting nickelate materials.
item.dc:title: Visualization of oxygen vacancies and self-doped ligand holes in La3Ni2O7−δ
item.dc:creator: Zehao Dong
Mengwu Huo
Jie Li
Jingyuan Li
Pengcheng Li
Hualei Sun
Lin Gu
Yi Lu
Meng Wang
Yayu Wang
Zhen Chen

item.title: China’s big-science bet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01597-1

With a view to increase its prestige and influence in global science, the country is investing heavily in major facilities.
item.dc:title: China’s big-science bet
item.dc:creator: James Mitchell Crow

item.title: Atomic-scale insights into the mystery of how ice surfaces melt
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01552-0

It has long been known that ice starts melting at temperatures far below its nominal freezing point, but why or how has remained enigmatic. An innovation in atomic force microscopy provides insights into how this process begins in the most abundant form of ice on Earth.
item.dc:title: Atomic-scale insights into the mystery of how ice surfaces melt

item.title: What we do — and don’t — know about how misinformation spreads online
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01618-z

There are gaps in our understanding of how and why digital misinformation propagates. To help design effective interventions to minimize the spread of falsehoods, researchers need data and transparency from online platforms.
item.dc:title: What we do — and don’t — know about how misinformation spreads online

item.title: A guide to the Nature Index
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01601-8

A description of the terminology and methodology used in this supplement, and a guide to the functionality that is available free online at natureindex.com.
item.dc:title: A guide to the Nature Index

item.title: Need a policy for using ChatGPT in the classroom? Try asking students
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01691-4

Students are the key users of AI chatbots in university settings, but their opinions are rarely solicited when crafting policies. That needs to change, says Maja Zonjić.
item.dc:title: Need a policy for using ChatGPT in the classroom? Try asking students
item.dc:creator: Maja Zonjić

item.title: How prevalent is AI misinformation? What our studies in India show so far
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01588-2

A sample of roughly two million WhatsApp messages highlights urgent concerns about the spread and prevalence of AI-generated political content.
item.dc:title: How prevalent is AI misinformation? What our studies in India show so far
item.dc:creator: Kiran Garimella
Simon Chauchard

item.title: A dad’s diet affects his sperm — and his sons’ health
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01623-2

Mouse fathers who ate high-fat foods and human fathers with high body-mass index have male offspring with metabolic disorders.
item.dc:title: A dad’s diet affects his sperm — and his sons’ health
item.dc:creator: Julian Nowogrodzki

item.title: Opioid drugs drive electrical insulation of reward circuitry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01630-3

Myelin is a fatty substance that forms an insulating sheath around the axons of neurons. In mice, drugs of abuse induce neuronal-activity-regulated changes in the myelination of neurons in the brain’s reward circuitry that release the neurotransmitter chemical dopamine. This myelin plasticity is required for the learning of reward associations with drugs of abuse, such as morphine.
item.dc:title: Opioid drugs drive electrical insulation of reward circuitry

item.title: Chinese research collaborations shift to the Belt and Road
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01598-0

Data from the Nature Index suggest changing make-up of international partnerships.
item.dc:title: Chinese research collaborations shift to the Belt and Road
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Plackett

item.title: A window on molecular chirality at the timescale of electron motion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01633-0

A laser technique, which has a time resolution of only a few femtoseconds, captures how photoexcited electrons can influence the chirality — or handedness — of neutral molecules. The resulting helical currents could be used to control physical and chemical properties that result from chiral interactions. This technology could have applications in fields ranging from solid-state electronics to drug design.
item.dc:title: A window on molecular chirality at the timescale of electron motion

item.title: Meta’s AI system is a boost to endangered languages — as long as humans aren’t forgotten
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01619-y

Automated approaches to translation could provide a lifeline to under-resourced languages, but only if companies engage with the people who speak them.
item.dc:title: Meta’s AI system is a boost to endangered languages — as long as humans aren’t forgotten

item.title: ‘I saw that discrimination wasn’t hearsay or rumours — it really did exist’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01685-2

JoAnn Trejo attributes her path to pharmacology to her immigrant family’s strong work ethic. Today, she uses recruitment and mentorship training to unlock the potential of other scientists from under-represented groups.
item.dc:title: ‘I saw that discrimination wasn’t hearsay or rumours — it really did exist’
item.dc:creator: Robin Donovan

item.title: Nuclei facing the tissue surface get fuel for development
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01503-9

Using tissue from the developing fruit-fly wing, researchers show that a nucleus’s location in the cell determines how it experiences signals that regulate genes needed for proper wing formation.
item.dc:title: Nuclei facing the tissue surface get fuel for development
item.dc:creator: Tanvi Kulkarni
Asifa Akhtar

item.title: Brain fluid probed by ultrasound using squishy cubes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01423-8

Soft solids that swell with shifts in pressure, temperature and pH provide a way of detecting such changes in the fluid around the brain. The method could be used to determine other properties of fluids elsewhere in the body.
item.dc:title: Brain fluid probed by ultrasound using squishy cubes
item.dc:creator: Jules J. Magda

item.title: This injectable gel can help to diagnose brain injury — then it disappears
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01673-6

The squishy sensors could be used to monitor the brain for tumours or injury, before eventually degrading.
item.dc:title: This injectable gel can help to diagnose brain injury — then it disappears
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: 1,001 best hikes on Mars: The Peterson Historic Trail (‘Peterson’s folly’)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01593-5

A walk into history.
item.dc:title: 1,001 best hikes on Mars: The Peterson Historic Trail (‘Peterson’s folly’)
item.dc:creator: Ron Fein

item.title: Precision dating pinpoints time between use of ancient fireplaces
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01501-x

Knowing the occupation timescales for ancient sites offers insights into population dynamics. A dating approach now establishes the time frame during which prehistoric hearths were in use at a high level of precision.
item.dc:title: Precision dating pinpoints time between use of ancient fireplaces
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Vandevelde

item.title: Huge amounts of bird-flu virus found in raw milk of infected cows
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01624-1

New findings point to the milking process as a possible route of avian-influenza spread between cows — and from cow to human.
item.dc:title: Huge amounts of bird-flu virus found in raw milk of infected cows
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: China’s research clout leads to growth in homegrown science publishing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01596-2

Self-reliance and a wish to set the agenda might explain concerted push to produce domestic journals.
item.dc:title: China’s research clout leads to growth in homegrown science publishing
item.dc:creator: Brian Owens

item.title: Chinese science still has room to grow
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01600-9

Strengths in chemistry and the physical sciences have propelled the country to the top of the Nature Index. But there is untapped potential in other subject areas.
item.dc:title: Chinese science still has room to grow

item.title: Meta’s AI translation model embraces overlooked languages
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00964-2

More than 7,000 languages are in use throughout the world, but popular translation tools cannot deal with most of them. A translation model that was tested on under-represented languages takes a key step towards a solution.
item.dc:title: Meta’s AI translation model embraces overlooked languages
item.dc:creator: David I. Adelani

item.title: Twitter suspended 70,000 accounts after the Capitol riots and it curbed misinformation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01690-5

Removal of users shows the role social media companies could play in preventing misinformation sharing — plus how physicists coaxed ultracold molecules into an exotic quantum state.
item.dc:title: Twitter suspended 70,000 accounts after the Capitol riots and it curbed misinformation
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Misinformation poses a bigger threat to democracy than you might think
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01587-3

In today’s polarized political climate, researchers who combat mistruths have come under attack and been labelled as unelected arbiters of truth. But the fight against misinformation is valid, warranted and urgently required.
item.dc:title: Misinformation poses a bigger threat to democracy than you might think
item.dc:creator: Ullrich Ecker
Jon Roozenbeek
Sander van der Linden
Li Qian Tay
John Cook
Naomi Oreskes
Stephan Lewandowsky

item.title: MDMA therapy for PTSD rejected by FDA panel
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01622-3

Scientific advisers to the US Food and Drug Administration vote overwhelmingly that the risks of MDMA treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder outweigh the benefits.
item.dc:title: MDMA therapy for PTSD rejected by FDA panel
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Drug-resistant infections more likely to strike women, says WHO
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01476-9

More countries must recognize how gender affects exposure to pathogens, finds a review by the World Health Organization.
item.dc:title: Drug-resistant infections more likely to strike women, says WHO
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Father’s diet influences son’s metabolic health through sperm RNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01502-w

DNA from organelles called mitochondria is not inherited from the father. But mitochondrial RNAs that sense paternal diet and mitochondrial quality are delivered from sperm to egg, affecting offspring metabolism.
item.dc:title: Father’s diet influences son’s metabolic health through sperm RNA
item.dc:creator: Chen Cai
Qi Chen

item.title: Why China has been a growing study destination for African students
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01599-z

Scholarships and soft power among reasons for increasing numbers, but graduates return with mixed reviews.
item.dc:title: Why China has been a growing study destination for African students
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer

item.title: Author Correction: Myt1l safeguards neuronal identity by actively repressing many non-neuronal fates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07594-8

Author Correction: Myt1l safeguards neuronal identity by actively repressing many non-neuronal fates
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Myt1l safeguards neuronal identity by actively repressing many non-neuronal fates

item.title: Mega engineering projects won’t stop a repeat of the devastating southern Brazil floods
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01665-6

Mega engineering projects won’t stop a repeat of the devastating southern Brazil floods

item.title: Underfunding cannabis research hampers sensible policymaking and boosts the black market
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01668-3

Underfunding cannabis research hampers sensible policymaking and boosts the black market
item.dc:title: Underfunding cannabis research hampers sensible policymaking and boosts the black market
item.dc:creator: Davoud Torkamaneh

item.title: Neurotechnologies that can read our mind could undermine international norms on freedom of thought
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01666-5

Neurotechnologies that can read our mind could undermine international norms on freedom of thought
item.dc:title: Neurotechnologies that can read our mind could undermine international norms on freedom of thought
